RE: SIMS, MICHAEL J DOB: 8/03/1952
DATE: 3/20/2018 JACKET #: 114556
PHY: Gordon L. Grado MD FACRO FACR

APPT TYPE: New Patient Visit—Glendale Offices

NARRATIVE: The patient is referred by Rev. S. K. The patient has a history of adenocarcinoma
of the prostate after diagnosis of rising PSA. History obtained from the patient and limited copies of records. The patient is a 65-year-old male
who is not sure if he has had PSAs in the past but saw his primary care physician, Dr. Michael
Brown. Digital rectal examinations have all been negative. On 08/16, PSA increased to 6.4
ng/m L. Dr. Brown recommended he see a urologist. Unfortunately, the patient had been on
Medicaid and lost his insurance. Medicare kicked in and he reestablished care with Dr. Brown. On 12/17, PSA 7.4 ng/m L. Digital rectal exam reported to be negative. The patient reports
nocturia four to five times with frequency every one hour. He was started on Flomax and
tamsulosin. He was recommended to see Dr. Vi Hua. No digital rectal exam was performed. Because of the rising/elevated PSA, the patient was recommended to undergo biopsy of the
prostate. Transrectal needle biopsy of the prostate gland was performed, which was quite
painful. Although the patient said that this was to have been done under local anesthesia, it was
extremely painful. Biopsy done, 02/13/18, pathology report #AS18-00147, noting Gleason 3+3=6
involving the right medial apex. The remainder of biopsy was negative for malignancy. Of note,
benign prostatic tissue was present in the right lateral apex, right medial mid base, and right
lateral base, and benign prostatic tissue with chronic inflammatory infiltrates right lateral mid
gland, left medial apex, left medial base, and left lateral base, and benign fibromuscular stroma
without prostate tissue in the left medial mid gland and left lateral mid gland. Specimen lengths
ranged from 0.1-1.5 cm. The prostate gland approximately 73 grams. After the biopsy, the patient had significant rectal bleeding for the entire evening. Again reported
biopsy extremely painful. Initial DRE from his urologist, 01/16/18, noted prostate gland reportedly
25 grams with nodule on right side 0.5 cm. The patient reported no DRE. The patient underwent
ultrasound examination, 01/18/18. The patient does not remember having any periprostatic
injection of anesthetic and reports the exam was extremely painful. By ellipsoid method, the
prostate gland measured 73.9 cc, height 48.3, width 55.4, and length 53.1. No gross hypoechoic
areas were reported on the right side. The patient reviewed options for therapy with his urologist
and was referred by his urologist to one of his radiation oncologists. A close friend had
recommended he come here for evaluation and exam and to discuss options. The patient
elected to come here by his friend and fellow pastor, Rev. S. K. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:

GU: The patient reports urinary frequency every 2 hours. He reports nocturia x2. He
denies any urgency, hesitancy, burning with urination. Hesitancy only if he skips
Flomax. Denies burning with urination, straining, or teakage. Urinary stream is
good. He feels he empties the bladder completely. He reports erections
adequate for intercourse without Viagra, Levitra, or Cialis. GENERAL: The patient denies any iumps, bumps, headaches, fevers, chills, night sweats,
weight loss, or other tumor-related complaints. Appetite is good. Energy level is
fine. MSs: Patient reports two years ago he woke up with pain in bilateral shoulders and
legs. The patient tried cortisone and it was better but only after five pills. He has
seen a chiropractor and has tried tumeric. Pain for one year. Patient took
tumeric blend for nerves and Ease. After two weeks, no pain. The patient tried
weaning off and pain returned. DERM: History of precancerous lesion on the nose. No other lesions or abnormalities. HEENT: Patient wears corrective lenses. No throat problems or hearing difficulties. CV: History of hypertension, controlled fairly well with borderline increased

cholesterol. No chest pain, MI, or edema. PULM: No shortness of breath, cough, hemoptysis, hematemesis, or sputum production. ENDO: No thyroid disease or diabetes.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: (continued)

NEURO: No seizure activity, stroke, or loss of consciousness. PSYCH: Negative. Gl: Bowel movements normal, two per day, without blood, mucus, straining,
constipation, or diarrhea. History of colonoscopy 15 years ago. INF DIS: Denied. No history of blood transfusions, hepatitis, STD, or HIV. CURRENT MEDICATIONS: Multivitamins, tamsulosin b.i.d., Ease, tumeric blend for nerves,
aspirin 81 mg, losartan, amlodipine. ALLERGIES: Denied. Allergy to IV contrast: Denied. FAMILY HISTORY: Grandfather with colon cancer. PREV RT: Denied. PREV CHEMO:
Denied. SURGICAL HX: Denied. SLEEP APNEA: Denied. SOCIAL HX: Patient is a pastor in
Avondale and running a food bank. Married with three children. ETOH: Rare. TOBACCO:
Denied. PHYSICAL EXAM:

GENERAL: Patient is a well-developed, well-nourished male in no acute distress and
appears stated age. Weight: 214 Ibs. Height: 5’8”. SKIN: In good condition. No abnormalities or lesions noted. No rashes, petechiae, or
ecchymosis. LUNGS: Clear to auscultation and percussion. Normal diaphragmatic excursion with
inspiration and expiration. CARDIAC: Grade 4/6 systolic ejection murmur. He reports undergoing extensive workup in
the past with diagnosis and no recommendations. Felt to be normal. BREASTS: Normal male bilaterally without masses, tenderness, or discharge. LNs: No significant peripheral lymph nodes palpable in the cervical, supraclavicular,
axillary, or inguinal areas. B&J: No bony percussion tenderness. Normal range of motion of all four extremities. NEURO: Cranial nerves II-XIl intact. Motor and sensory within normal limits. Patient
oriented X 3. ABDOMEN: Soft, nontender without masses. No significant HSM. Normal bowel sounds
present in all four quadrants. HEENT: Normocephalic. PERRLA. EOMI. No oral pathology identified. Trachea
midline. GU: Testes are descended bilaterally. Penis circumcised without lesions. RECTAL: No rectal masses were noted. Biopsy site noted, anterior rectal wall, involving

the rectal wall. PROSTATE: Two nodules noted on the left side of the prostate gland, left base and left apex,
and a larger mass noted in right apex. IMPRESSION: 1) Rising/elevated PSA. 2) History of adenocarcinoma of the prostate. 3) History
of hypertension. TREATMENT PLAN/RECOMMENDATION: | had a long discussion with the patient regarding the
options for therapy including the rationale, risks, goals, side effects, and alternatives. Discussed
at length and detail with specifics. Questions answered. During discussion, we reviewed options
including unconventional forms of therapy, cryotherapy, hyperthermia, particle beam irradiation
therapy, robot-assisted surgery, watchful waiting, chemotherapy, androgen deprivation therapy,
surgery (and its various options), and radiation therapy (and its various options). Side effects
discussed both acute to chronic and minimal to severe. The side effects discussion included but
was not limited to the discussion of bowel and bladder changes, bowel and bladder damage,

need for surgical correction, impotence, incontinence, bleeding, infection, nerve injury, fissure,
fistula. Also discussed published literature. The patient was led to believe that brachytherapy
was no longer utilized in treating prostate cancer. | indicated this was certainly not the case but
that brachytherapy had to be offered for the appropriate reasons and clinical picture. Following
discussion and review, the patient wished to proceed with radiation therapy. In this setting
because of the hard nodule identified, rectal wall changes, rising PSA, abnormal with prostate
digital rectal examination; | would recommend a combination of XRT and brachytherapy as the
best treatment or XRT alone. This discussed at length and detail. Following discussion and
review, the patient wished to proceed. This report has been electronically signed and Approved by Gordon L. Grado, MD, FACRO,

The patient was met coming in the operating room. He again recognized me, confirmed his
identity, described well the planned procedure. The patient consented to proceed. He
participated in the timeout in the OR. Following suitable general endotracheal anesthesia with an LMA, the patient prepped and draped
in dorsal lithotomy position. I noted that the ultrasound cradle and the B&K stepper stabilize
unit had been tampered with and repair was required. I notified the OR nurse manager. The bladder was drained of urine and filled in retrograde manner with contrast. Retrograde
cystogram Was negative. A Foley catheter was placed in bladder to identify coarse of the urethra
through the gland. Retrograde cystogram was negative. Foley catheter in place to identify the
course of urethra. This also provided help with stabilization of the prostate gland during the
procedure. An ulttasound volume study was performed and compared to preop scan, Modification plan was
necessary due to changes in size and shape of the prostate. Prior to the procedure, the prostate
Bland measured 45.4 x 49.5 x 62.5 mm, for a volute of 66 m L, Today the prostate gland
measured 42, x 50 x 60 mm, for a volume of 65.7 m L. A different needle placement was
performed. I began by placing the needles in rows 5, followed by row 4. These needles were
then cheoked both by biplane ulirasound and fluoroscopic guidance before attaching a Mick TP
200 applicator to each needle and depositing radioactive seeds as each needle was withdrawn, I
then placed needles in row 3 and again each needle's position was checked before depositing
seads with the Mick TP 200 applicator. I then proceeded to rows 1 and 2. Prior to placing
needles in tow 1, a K3 needle was utilized to circumnavigate the rectal bump below the apex of
the prostate gland bringing the rectal bump posteriorly, the apex postetiorly, separated frarn the
tect, and then the base anteriorly. These needles were then advanced to the base of the
prostate gland and then placed __ row 2, The patient tolerated the procedure well,

At the end of this procedure, the space between needles were then checked. Two additional
trocars were placed at rows 1/1/2 bilaterally laterally, 2/1/2 bilaterally laterally, and row 3/1/2
bilaterally laterally before advancing needles to the base of the gland and depositing seeds as
each needle was withdrawn from the patient. A total of 205 seeds of 0.21 millicurie per seed
from Iso Aid wete deposited. At the end of the procedure, space was noted to have developed
between the prostate gland and rectum. This was facilitated by additional needle placement in
this space to create a hematoma. At the end of the procedure, direct pressure was applied to the
prostate gland below apex to reduce swelling and bleeding within the gland. The patient
tolerated the procedure well,

Will plan to see him back in our office for dosimetry studies and images. Gordon Grado,

Prior to procedure, I noted that the stepper stabilize unit and ultrasound cradle had been tampered
with. These were repaired to permit proceeding with the patient's case. Following suitable general endotracheal anesthesia, patient prepped and draped in dorsal
lithotomy position. A, perioperative ultrasound volume study was perfortned and compared to
preop scan, Modification plan was necessary due to changes in size, shape of the prostate. This
was accorntodated intraoperatively, Prior to the procedure, the patient had undergone
ultrasound volume study measuring 45,4 x 49.5 x 62.5 mtn, for a volume of 66 rl. Today the
prostate measured 42 x 50 x 60 mm, fora voliune of 65.7 m L. A biplane implant was
developed, but needle placement was modified, The space betweet the rectum and the prostate
gland was analyzed, This had increased due to the previous XRT procedure and prepatation. A Foley catheter was placed in the bladder. This to identify course of urethra through the pland. Retrograde cystogram was negative. The catheter was left in place to identify coarse of the
utethra through the prostate, A dummy gold seed was placed at the apex of the prostate on
patient's right side, This to identify the inferior extent. I began first by placing needles in row 5;
followed by row 4, then rows 3 by itself, then rows 1 and 2. After each row of needles wete in
proper position, each needle's position was checked both by biplane ultrasound and fluoroscopic
guidance, The stylets were then removed from the needle through which radioactive jodine-125
seeds were inserted as cach needle was withdrawn from the patient. The patient tolerated the
procedure well, The patient had large blood vessels noted at the apex of the prostate gland on
the right side greater than left. Also increased blood vessels noted throughout the prostate. This
caused some movement of the seeds within the prostate gland during deposition. Because we
were doing fluoroscopy, I could see that occurring and then could accommodate accordingly. A
GE OEC C-anm was ‘utilized during the procedure for the fluoroscopy and a B&K. Leopard
ultrasound unit with model 8551 multi-hertz probe. In placing needles in row 1, I used a K3

____sneedie to circumnavigate the rectal bump below the apex of the prostate gland. This allowed =
depression of the rectum posteriorly and then entering the prostate. This allowed me to move the
apex posittiorly and the base anteriorly. After needles were placed in row 1, 1 then proceeded to
row 2. After all needles were in position, all seeds deposited, all needles removed from the
patient. I then placed 2 additional needles in row 1/1/2 bilaterally laterally, 2/1/2 bilaterally
laterally, and 3~1/2 bilaterally laterally to accommodate prostate gland movement that occurred
during the process, as well as seed movement. At the end of the procedure, a total of 205 seeds
of 0.21 millicurie per seed from Iso Aid were utilized. Two seeds had noted to pass within the
bladder, One seed was able to be recovered and transported back to hot lab for disposal and
decay, Will plan to see the patient back in our office before distuissal,

DIAGNOSIS: Clinical stage B3 (T2c), Gleason 3+3=6 adenocarcinoma of the prostate

by prostate brachytherapy I-125 seeds 5/16/18

PATIENT LAST SEEN: 05/16/18

DATE OF SERVICE: 09/04/18

NARRATIVE: Patient seen today for his first follow up visit having completed radiation therapy
for prostate cancer. The patient reports “I am doing okay, | think". The patient is still having
some urinary symptoms. He still has some hesitancy and incomplete emptying of bladder. He
notes getting up at night. He reports that he has been getting used to having burning sensation
with urination. Burning sensation seems to begin in the prostate gland and radiates out to the
end of the penis. In addition, patient had noted some burning sensation to the rectum but this
has resolved. He reports being treated for infection x2 through Dr. Nelson's office. The
antibiotics “seemed to help”. It did not eliminate the discomfort. The patient was advised that the
swelling of the prostate gland is the source of discomfort and pain either radiating to the rectum or
the penis. We discussed other symptoms. He denies any difficulties. He denies heavy lifting or
strenuous activities. He denies problems with constipation or straining with bowel movements or
sitting on the commode for a period of time. He reviews the burning sensation in the penis. Itis less. In the past it had traveled to the rectum
but has resolved. it goes posteriorly and anteriorly. He reports that it does occur every time he
voids but varies in degree. The patient's PSA history was reviewed.

08/16 PSA 6.4. ng/m L
12/17 PSA 7.4.ng/m L
08/22/18 PSA 1.4 ng/m L, testosterone 409

Patient is pleased with response and results. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:

dysfunction. Gl: Bowel movements without blood, mucus, straining, or constipation. He does

have some looser stools. Patient reports stools are short loose bursts. He
reports being very gassy but notes this began after taking a high-fiber smoothy
every morning. | advised against that and recommended fiber in diet with
Citrucel powder in the a.m. MS: History of precancerous lesions on nose. DERM: No skin cancers or lesions. HEENT: No history of hearing difficulties. No throat problems or complaints. No vision
disturbances reported. CV: No chest pain, MI, or edema. Patient has heart murmur. PULM: No shortness of breath, cough, hemoptysis, hematemesis, or sputum production. ENDO: No thyroid disease or diabetes,

NEURO: No seizure activity, stroke, or loss of consciousness. PSYCH: Negative. CURRENT MEDICATIONS: Flomax b.i.d., cholesterol medication.
